For information about these properties, see an HTML reference.
getViewProperty.invoke: Causes the property value to load.
getViewProperty.objectPath: Specifies the path of the component to get a property for. For the parent of this dataflow block, enter @parent.
getViewProperty.output: Returns the value of the property.
Google_Map.data: Specifies the table from which latitude and longitude data for location markers can be determined.
Google_Map.symbol: Specifies the symbol to be used as a location marker. If the symbol is in this project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol.
gradient: Specifies the colors for a gradient fill. To add colors, click below the track in the dialog. To delete colors, right−click on them in the dialog. For a heat map, the left color indicates the lowest intensity, middle colors indicates medium intensity, and the right color indicates the highest intensity.
gradientMapping.input: Specifies the number to translate to a color in the gradient.
gradientMapping.max: Specifies the maximum of the number scale, corresponding to the right end of the gradient.
gradientMapping.min: Specifies the minimum of the number scale, corresponding to the left end of the gradient.
gradientMapping.output: Returns the color in the gradient that corresponds to the input's position in the number range.
gradientStop.alpha: Specifies the opacity of the selected fill color in the gradient.
gradientStop.ratio: Specifies the position of the selected fill color in the gradient. A value of 0% positions the selected color at the leftmost edge of the track that Specifies the gradient. A value of 100% positions it at the rightmost edge.
gridColumn.!label: Specifies the label to be used as heading text for columns controlled by this column editor. [More information].
gridColumn.category: Specifies the category to which this column belongs. Must match the Selector property of some other column editor in this grid. [More information]
gridColumn.headerSymbol: Specifies the symbol that appears in the header of the columns affected by this column editor. If the symbol is in this project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol.
gridColumn.selector:
Specifies which data types or columns this column editor controls. The contents of the property depends on the column editor type, as follows:
  • All: No effect.
  • Name: Specifies the name of a table column.
  • Repeater: Specifies which column of the configuration table contains the data table column names.
gridColumn.sortable: Specifies whether the columns affected by this column editor are sortable.
gridColumn.sortAsc: Sorts the data using this column, in ascending order. Using this trigger changes the Sort Order to Ascending, under Data Grid properties.
gridColumn.sortDesc: Sorts the data using this column, in descending order. Using this trigger changes the Sort Order to Descending, under Data Grid properties.
gridColumn.sortingIndicator: Specifies whether a graphic appears in the column that currently sorts the data. The Sorting Indicator property for a Name column editor overrides the Sorting Indicator property for an All column editor.
gridColumn.symbol: Specifies the symbol that appears in each cell of the columns affected by this column editor. If the symbol is in this project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol.
gridColumn.type:
Specifies the kind of column group this column editor controls. [More information].
  • All: An All column editor dictates that all of the columns from the source table are included in the grid, except for those that you filter out of the entire grid. Grid columns appear in source table order, unless you specify another order using a whitelist filter. Properties edited for this column editor apply to all columns.
  • Name: Each Name column editor dictates that one column from the source table is included in the grid. Grid columns appear in the order in which they appear in the Outline, unless you specify another order using a whitelist filter. Properties edited for this column editor apply to this column.
  • Repeater: A Repeater column editor lets you use a configuration table to determine which source table columns appear in the grid, which symbols represent those columns (if any), and properties of the symbols.
gridColumn.visible:
Specifies whether this component is visible. Regardless of value, the component affects layout and is stored in the user's browser memory. Because the component is stored in memory, performance might be affected.

TRUE: This component is visible.

FALSE: This component is not visible, but it still affects layout and is stored in browser memory.
gridlines.gridDirection: Specifies which gridlines are displayed in the plotting area of the chart. You can choose to have horizontal only, vertical only, both, or none.
gridlines.horizontalAlternateFill: Specifies the second of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between horizontal gridlines. The first is defined by the Horizontal Fill property.
gridlines.horizontalChangeCount: Specifies the number of tick marks between horizontal grid lines. For example, to draw a grid line at every third tick mark along the axis, set the property to 3.
gridlines.horizontalFill: Specifies the first of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between horizontal gridlines. The second is defined by the Horizontal Alternate Fill property.
gridlines.horizontalOriginStrokeWidth: Weight in pixels of horizontal origin line.
gridlines.horizontalStroke: Specifies the stroke color for horizontal gridlines.
gridlines.horizontalStrokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for horizontal gridlines. A stroke weight greater than 0 overrides a stroke style of None.
gridlines.horizontalStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for horizontal gridlines.
gridlines.horizontalTickAligned:
Specifies where horizontal gridlines are placed.

TRUE: Horizontal gridlines are positioned at major ticks.

FALSE: Horizontal gridlines are positioned halfway between major ticks.
gridlines.plottedAreaHeight: (Read−only) Returns the height of the plot area in pixels.
gridlines.plottedAreaWidth: (Read−only) Returns the width of the plot area in pixels.
gridlines.plottedAreaX: (Read−only) Returns the view x−coordinate at the left edge of the plotted area.
gridlines.plottedAreaY: (Read−only) Returns the view y−coordinate at the top edge of the plotted area.
gridlines.verticalAlternateFill: Specifies the second of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalChangeCount: Specifies the number of tick marks between vertical grid lines. For example, to draw a grid line at every third tick mark along the axis, set the property to 3.
gridlines.verticalFill: Specifies the first of two fills that alternate in the plotting area between vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalOriginStrokeWidth: Weight inpixesl for vertical origina line.
gridlines.verticalStroke: Specifies the stroke color for vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalStrokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for vertical gridlines. A stroke weight greater than 0 overrides a stroke style of None.
gridlines.verticalStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for vertical gridlines.
gridlines.verticalTickAligned:
Specifies where vertical gridlines are placed.

TRUE: Vertical gridlines are positioned at major ticks.

FALSE: Vertical gridlines are positioned halfway between major ticks.
hAlign:
Determines how components are horizontally aligned.
  • Left: The leftmost edge of the image or tiles is justified to the left container boundary.
  • Center: The image or tiles are horizontally centered.
  • Right: The rightmost edge of the image or tiles is justified to the right container boundary.
hCenter: In absolute or vertical layout, sets the horizontal center of this component to a distance to the left or right of the the horizontal center of its parent container. The value can be pixels, or a percent of the parent width. A negative value moves this component to the left, and a positive value moves it to the right. A value of Auto positions the horizontal center of this component in its normal position in the layout. To set a value of Auto, click the blue dot and select Reset.
heatMap.dataField:
Specifies the table column from which the intensity values are determined.

"Intensity" refers to whatever units the heat map is measuring, for example temperature or air flow. Each data point on the heat map has an intensity value that determines its color.

Intensity values range from 0 to the highest data value. An intensity of 0 corresponds to the left end of this heat map's gradient, and the highest intensity value corresponds to the right end of this heat map's gradient.
heatMap.falloff: Specifies the percentage of each heat map item that is covered by the highest intensity color for that shape. The specified inner portion of the shape is covered by the color representing the intensity of the data point. The remaining outer portion of the shape blends from the color of this intensity value to the color of an intensity value of zero.
heatMap.radius: Specifies the radius of each item on the heat map.
heatMap.showLegend: Specifies whether to show a simple legend in the heat map component.
heatMap.xField: Specifies the table column from which the X values of the heat map data points are determined. Each X value is a distance in pixels from the left edge of the component.
heatMap.yField: Specifies the table column from which the Y values of the heat map data points are determined. Each Y value is a distance in pixels from the top edge of the component.
height:
Specifies the height of this component, as a pixel value, a percentage of the parent width, or Auto. To ensure the most responsive layouts, enable Auto height whenever possible. To set Auto height, click the blue dot and select Reset. You can use Auto height in the following ways:
  • Stretch — For all components, when the parent layout is Horizontal, and vertical alignment is Stretch, use Auto height to make this component's height inherit the parent height. Does not work properly for calendars, or with wrapping.
  • Flex−Grow — For all components, when the parent layout is Vertical, use Auto height together with Flex−Grow to cause this component and its siblings to share the entire parent height. Alternatively, you can use Flex−Grow with a pixel or percent size, but Auto is usually a better choice.
  • Text Components — Use Auto height to make this component's height follow the content height. If Auto width is also used, the component follows the content size.
  • Symbols — Use Auto height to cause this container to follow the content height. Only works if the boolean autoSize property is set to TRUE, and the internal symbol width and height are is in pixels.
  • Groups — Use Auto height to make this group's width follow the content width. Only works when this group's layout is vertical or horizontal.
  • Page Includes — Use Auto height to cause this container to follow the content height. Only works if the boolean autoSize property is set to TRUE, and the internal content height is set to pixels or percent.
  • Videos — Use Auto height and a pixel or percent width to make this component's height follow the content aspect ratio without growing taller than the content. Depending on the width, part of the container might be empty. If Auto width is also used, the component follows the content size.
hGap: Specifies the minimum number of pixels between components in a horizontal layout, or between columns in a wrapped vertical layout. When Horizontal Alignment is Flex−Start, Horizontal Gap Specifies a right padding, but you must define a left padding separately. For all other horizontal alignments, Horizontal Gap Specifies a left padding, but you must define a right padding separately.
hideBackFace: Specifies whether a component is visible when it is not facing the screen. Useful when an component is rotated and you do not want to see its back side. Not supported by iOS.
highlightedBackground: Specifies the fill for highlighted the cells the user mouses over, or the highlighted cells specified using the Property Inspector
highlightedBorder: Specifies the stroke color or border image for outlining the cells the user mouses over, or the highlighted cells specified using the Property Inspector
highlightedCornerRadius: Specifies the rounded corners for the cells the user mouses over, or the highlighted cells specified using the Property Inspector, as arcs of circles or ellipses. The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the cell's width and height, respectively. A value of 0 means that corners are not rounded.
highlightedFontColor: Specifies the font color for numbers in the cells the user mouses over, or the highlighted cells specified using the Property Inspector.
highlightedFontFamily:
Specifies the font for numbers in the cells the user mouses over, or the highlighted cells specified using the Property Inspector. To add a font to your project:
  1. If your project does not have a fonts folder, right−click the root folder for your project, and add a folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
highlightedFontSize: Specifies the font size for numbers in the cells the user mouses over, or the highlighted cells specified using the Property Inspector.
highlightedFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in highlighted cells is italic.
highlightedFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in highlighted cells is bold.
highlightedStyle: For internal use, do not change.
hScroll:
Specifies horizontal scrolling behavior on this component.
  • Off: Horizontal scrolling is always disabled.
  • On: Horizontal scrolling is always enabled. The track appears even if the content does not overflow.
  • Auto: Horizontal scrolling is automatically enabled when content overflows.
hub.0: Sets and returns one of the values watched by this hub.
hub.index: Returns the index of the input n value that was updated most recently. The index is the number in the input's property name. For example, when input 0 updates at 11:00am, and input 1 updates at 11:05am, index is 1 because input 1 updated last.
hub.onChange: Event fired when the output changes.
hub.output: Returns the value of the most recently updated input n property.
hZoomMax: Sets or returns the maximum of the range on the horizontal axis for the zoomed view. If either Minimum or Maximum is null, the zoom does not happen. Zooming works only with linear, log, and datetime axes. For dates, use the format "yyyyMMdd".
hZoomMin: Sets or returns the minimum of the range on the horizontal axis for the zoomed view. If either Minimum or Maximum is null, the zoom does not happen. Zooming works only with linear, log, and datetime axes. For dates, use the format "yyyyMMdd".
hZoomTrigger: Zooms the chart to the range specified by the Horizontal Zoom Minimum and Maximum. To return the chart to its pre−zoom view, the user can click on the chart. Zooming works only with linear, log, and datetime axes.
if.0: An input to the IF block, to be evaluated using the specified operator.
if.else: Specifies the value to return if the expression evaluates to FALSE. To display the word FALSE, use the logical value FALSE for this parameter. else can be an input from another block or set of blocks, including formulas.
if.op:
Specifies the arithmetic, comparison, or text operator to apply to the input values. It is used in conjunction with input n to form an expression that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE. For example, "input 0 = input 1" is a logical expression. If the value in input 0 is equal to the value in input 1, the expression evaluates to TRUE. Otherwise, the expression evaluates to FALSE.
  • = (equal to) — The expression is TRUE if all input values are equal.
  • > (greater than) — The expression is TRUE if each input value is greater than the value that immediately follows it.
  • < (less than) — The expression is TRUE if each input value is less than the value that immediately follows it.
  • >= (greater than or equal to) — The expression is TRUE if each input value is greater than or equal to the value that immediately follows it.
  • <= (less than or equal to) — The expression is TRUE if each input value is less than or equal to the value that immediately follows it.
  • != (not equal to) — The expression is TRUE if all input values are different. No two can be equal.
  • and — The expression is TRUE if all input values evaluate to TRUE.
  • or — The expression is TRUE if one or more input values evaluate to TRUE.
if.output: Returns either the then value or the else value. It returns the then value if the expression evaluates to TRUE, and the else value otherwise
if.then: Specifies the value to return if the expression evaluates to TRUE. To display the word TRUE, use the logical value TRUE for this parameter. then can be an input from another block or set of blocks, including formulas.
IFrame.refresh: Triggers a refresh of the IFrame.
iframe.scrolling: Specifies whether scrolling is enabled on the IFrame component. If this is disabled, then content that overflows the component is clipped.
IFrame.url: Specifies the URL of the content to be displayed in the IFrame. You can use third−party or your own standalone CSS, JavaScript, and HTML components in your application. Your custom components appear as if they were native components.
iframeMessage.autoRun: Specifies whether the message is sent automatically when the page loads.
iframeMessage.enabled:
Specifies whether message sending is enabled.

TRUE: Messages are sent as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE: No messages are sent.
iframeMessage.interval: Specifies how often the message is sent automatically, in seconds. A value of 0 means that it is sent on autoRun or invoke only.
iframeMessage.invoke: Causes the message to be sent. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
iframeMessage.key: key and match specify a key−value pair that must be matched somewhere in the JSON message, in order for the message to be sent. Use a value of * for match to accept any value for the specified key. Use these properties when sending a message.
iframeMessage.loading: Returns TRUE if the message is currently being sent, FALSE otherwise.
iframeMessage.match: key and match specify a key−value pair that must be matched somewhere in the JSON message, in order for the message to be sent. Use a value of * for match to accept any value for the specified key. Use these properties when sending a message.
iframeMessage.matchRegExp: Specifies a regular expression that the message must match.
iframeMessage.message: Holds the message to send, if it is a JSON string. Use this property when sending a message from Solution Builder.
iframeMessage.timeout: Specifies in seconds how long the sending attempt will continue before it is canceled.
img.!numFrames: (Read−only) Returns the number of frames in the animation, not including the image. Add frames by clicking the Add button.
img.@onComplete: Triggers an event on completion of this animation. Can be used to invoke actions or trigger other events.
img.active: Sets or returns whether the animation is currently running.
img.breakApart: Separates an SVG into its component vectors to enable you to edit it.
img.frameIndex: (Read−only) Returns the index of the frame currently displayed in the animation. The image defined by the URL property is 0, the topmost frame in the animation sequence is 1, and so on.
img.frames: Specifies the paths to each of the frames in the animation sequence. Click Add to add frames, and then specify an image path for each frame.
img.intervalMillis: Specifies how long each frame is displayed, in seconds.
img.isAnimator:
Specifies whether the image component animates a specified list of frames.

The image defined by the URL property is displayed only when the animation is not active.
img.reverse:
Determines whether the animation frames are displayed in reverse.

TRUE: The topmost frame in the Property Inspector appears first in the animation sequence.

FALSE: The bottommost frame in the Property Inspector appears first in the animation sequence.
img.src: Specifies the path where the image is located. Click the folder icon to select or upload an image, or enter a relative URL within the project, such as assets/image.png. You can also enter any absolute URL, even if it is outside of your project. You can use any image format that is supported by the user's browser.
inputOutOfRange: TRUE if the input is outside the range, FALSE otherwise.
isRepeaterMode: Enable repeater mode for stacker (dynamic number of series).
isValid: Indicates whether this component's current contents are valid. Validity is determined by the component type and by properties like Minimum, Maximum, and Input Type. Validity is checked whenever data is committed. Therefore, if Live Update is enabled, validity is checked constantly. If Live Update is disabled, validity is checked when the focus leaves the component.
javascript.a: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.autoRun:
Specifies whether the script runs automatically.

TRUE
The script runs every time the script is changed, and every time any property is changed, including the first time that the script is initialized.

FALSE
The script runs only when the invoke property is triggered.
javascript.b: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.c: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.d: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.e: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.f: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.g: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.i: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.initFunction: Specifies the name of the init function in the file.
javascript.invoke: Causes the JavaScript to be loaded in the global source for the page and runs the init function.
javascript.j: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.k: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.l: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.m: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.n: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.o: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.p: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.q: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.r: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.s: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.scriptPath: Specifies the path to the JavaScript file. It can be a file path relative to the root, or it can be some other URL. The file extension must be .js.
javascript.t: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.u: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.v: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.w: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.x: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.y: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
javascript.z: Set or return the values of properties that you can use in your script as needed.
jsonParser.drillDownDepth: Specifies how far to drill down into the JSON when extracting data. Data below the drillDownDepth is not included in the output. Only works when a drillDownFilter or flatFilter is specified.
jsonParser.drillDownFilter: Specifies what to return for nested tables. Enter * to return all nested tables to the specified drillDownDepth. For more information about nested tables, see How do I view the data in nested tables?
jsonParser.flatFilter: Specifies what to return for a flat table. Enter * to return all data to the specified drillDownDepth, in a flat table.
jsonParser.input: Receives the JSON string. Sometimes it is the output from a String Loader block.
jsonParser.output: Returns a table parsed from the JSON data.
jsonParser.parseError: Indicates whether the block encountered an error. An error might be caused by improperly formatted input.
jsonParser.selector: Specifies the location of the data in the JSON string to parse into a table.
jsonpLoader.autoRun:
Specifies whether the data is loaded automatically.

TRUE
The data is loaded every time any property is changed. This includes the first time that the url property is populated.

FALSE
The data is loaded only when the invoke property is triggered, or at the specified interval.
jsonpLoader.callback: Specifies the name of the callback function used to retrieve the data. This function must be defined at the URL. You might be able to copy the function name from the URL string, or you might need to find it at the URL.
jsonpLoader.enabled:
Specifies whether the loader is active.

TRUE: The JSONP data is retrieved as specified by invoke, interval, and autoRun.

FALSE: Nothing happens when this block is invoked.
jsonpLoader.interval: Specifies how often the loader gets data, in seconds.
jsonpLoader.invoke: Causes the data to be loaded. Only works when enabled is set to TRUE.
jsonpLoader.loading: Returns whether the block is currently loading data.
jsonpLoader.onComplete: Fires when the JSON string is loaded.
jsonpLoader.timeout: Specifies how long the loader will attempt to load the string before the request is canceled.
jsonpLoader.url: Specifies the location of the JSON string.
justifyContent:
Specifies the horizontal positioning of all components within this container.
  • Flex−Start: Elements are packed against the left edge.
  • Flex−End: Elements are packed against the right edge.
  • Center: Elements are packed together around the horizontal center.
  • Space−Between: Elements are distributed with the left component flush against the left edge, the right component flush against the right edge, and equal space between the items. Only available when the Layout property is set to Horizontal.
  • Space−Around: Elements are distributed with equal space between them. The space at the left and right of the container equals half of the space between two adjacent items. Only available when the Layout property is set to Horizontal.
  • Baseline: The baseline of all components is aligned to the baseline of the parent container. Only available when the Layout property is set to Vertical.
  • Stretch: Elements stretch horizontally to fit the parent container. Only works when the components have a height value of Auto and the Layout property is set to Vertical.
keepAspectRatio: Maintains the aspect ratio of this component when its width or height properties are adjusted. If this component's width or height is set to Auto, it has no explicit aspect ratio, and this property does nothing.
keepEqualPaddings: Links all four padding editors so that their values are equal.
keyboardCapture:
Specifies keyboard processing policy. Keyboard events are required for focus processing and to get keyboard events (@onKeyDown, @onKeyUp) from the GUI.
  • default: Process keyboard events only if component is focused.
  • all: Process all keyboard events from component's root.
  • global: Process all keyboard events from document.
keyboardEventData.active: Sets or returns whether this block is currently listening for the specified event.
keyboardEventData.alt: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Alt is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Alt was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.ctrl: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Ctrl is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Ctrl was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.event: Returns the name of the event type that triggers this block, such as onKeyDown.
keyboardEventData.filter:
Specifies the keystroke to listen for. This can be a character, or one of the following strings:

  • esc — Escape key
  • enter — Enter or Return key
  • up — Up arrow
  • down — Down arrow
  • left — Left arrow
  • right — Right arrow
  • Combination strings such as "alt+enter"
keyboardEventData.input:
Specifies the event that triggers this block. Make sure that you have selected the correct parent component for the event, and then find the event in the Advanced properties and bind it to this property. Valid events are:

  • onKeyDown — The user depresses a key while the component is in focus.
  • onKeyUp — The user releases the depressed key.
keyboardEventData.keyCode: Returns the key code of the last key to undergo key down or key up, whichever was specified. Refer to instances of JavaScript keyCode.
keyboardEventData.meta: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Meta is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Meta was the last key down.
keyboardEventData.output: Fires when the specified event occurs.
keyboardEventData.shift: For an onKeyUp event, returns whether Shift is still being held, if it was held with the last key typed. For anOnKeyDown event, returns whether Shift was the last key down.
keyColumn: For use with repeaters. If set, contains the name of column from which all values (cells) for selected items are extracted into the selectedValue property. For a multiple selection, selectedValue is populated with a comma−separated list of values.
label.align: Specifies how the label is aligned.
label.borderColor: Specifies the color of the label's border.
label.label: Label
Specifies label text.
labelAlign:
For a vertical axis, determines whether the labels are aligned vertically to the top, middle, or bottom of the major ticks.

For a horizontal axis, determines whether the labels are aligned to the left, center, or right of the major ticks.
labelGap: Specifies the distance, in pixels, between the major tick marks and the labels for this axis.
labelRotation: Specifies the angle of rotation for the labels on this axis. Valid values are between −90 and 90.
labelsColor: Specifies the font color used for the labels along this axis.
labelsFontSize: Specifies the font size used for the labels along an axis.
labelsFontStyle: Specifies whether these labels are italic.
labelsFontWeight: Specifies whether these labels are bold.
labelsLetterSpacing: Specifies the horizontal spacing between characters. A null value means the font's default spacing is used.
labelsTextDecoration: Specifies whether these labels are underlined.
labelToEdgeGap: Specifies the distance, in pixels, between the chart container and the labels for this axis.
latitude: Sets or returns the latitude at the center of the map component.
layout:
Specifies how components are positioned within this container.
  • Absolute: Elements are positioned freely.
  • Horizontal: Elements are positioned in order horizontally left to right.
  • Vertical: Elements are positioned in order vertically top to bottom.
left: In an absolute layout, sets the left edge of this component to a distance to the left or right of the left edge of its parent container. In a vertical or horizontal layout, sets the left edge of this component to a distance to the left or right of its normal position. Distances are specified in pixels or as percentages of the parent width. A value of Auto positions the left edge of this component in its normal position. To set a value of Auto, click the blue dot and select Reset.
left.input: Specifies the text string that contains the characters to extract.
left.length: Specifies how many characters to extract.
length.input: Specifies the text to find the length for. Spaces count as characters.
length.output: Returns the number of characters in the input string.
letterSpacing: Specifies the horizontal spacing between characters. If null, the default spacing for the selected font is used.
lineHeight: Specifies the vertical spacing between lines of text.
lineSeries.lineStroke: Specifies the outline stroke color for the line series.
lineSeries.lineStrokeStyle: Outline line style for the line series.
lineSeries.lineStrokeWidth: Specifies the outline stroke weight in pixels for the line series.
lineSeries.symbol: Specifies the symbol to use for custom markers. To use a symbol from this project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol. When you populate this field with a symbol, the marker's item renderer appears in the Outline as a child of this series, and you can bind table columns to symbol properties in the Property Inspector.
list.fontFamily: Specifies the font display for an item when the item is selected.
listFiles.autoRun:
Specifies whether the table is generated automatically.

TRUE
The table is generated every time any property is changed. This includes the first time that the path property is populated.

FALSE
The table is generated only when the invoke property is triggered, or at the specified interval.
listFiles.enabled:
Specifies whether the block is enabled.

TRUE: The table is created as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE: The table is not created.
listFiles.filter:
Specifies a string that file names must include to be listed, such as a file extension. Directories are always included in the output if mode is All or Directories. They are not filtered by this property.
  • To list only PNG files, enter png.
  • To list all files, leave this field blank.
listFiles.interval: Specifies how often the table is automatically generated. A value of 0 means that the table is generated on autoRun or invoke only.
listFiles.invoke: Causes the table to be created. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
listFiles.loading: Returns whether the list is currently loading.
listFiles.mode:
Specifies whether the output table lists only files, only directories, or both.
  • All: Files and directories are listed.
  • Files: Only files are listed.
  • Directories: Only directories are listed.
listFiles.onComplete: Fires when the table is finished loading.
listFiles.output:
Returns a table that lists the contents of the specified directory. The table includes the following fields:

  • name — the filename or directory name.
  • path — the path of the item, relative to the root.
  • isDirectory — TRUE if the item is a directory, FALSE if it is a file.
  • created — 0, if the item is a directory. The serial number for the creation date and time, if it is a file.
  • modified — 0, if the item is a directory. The serial number for the last update date and time, if it is a file.
listFiles.path:
Specifies the directory for which to create a table.

  • To list the contents of the root, leave this field blank.
  • To list the contents of the assets folder, drag the folder from the Project panel to this field.
listFiles.timeout: Specifies how long the block will attempt to create the table before the request is canceled.
listFormElement.arrowImage: Specifies a custom arrow graphic that appears if Show Arrow is enabled. If you don't specify an image, a default graphic is used.
listFormElement.color: Specifies the font color for the selected option.
listFormElement.fontFamily:
Specifies the font for the selected option. To add a font to your project:
  1. If your project does not have a fonts folder, right−click the root folder for your project, and add a folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
listFormElement.fontSize: Specifies the font size for the selected option.
listFormElement.fontStyle: Specifies whether the selected option is italic.
listFormElement.fontWeight: Specifies whether the selected option is bold.
listFormElement.optionBackground: Specifies the fill for the options list. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionColor: Specifies the font color for the options list. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionFontFamily:
Specifies the font for the options list. Not supported in all browsers. To add a font to your project:
  1. If your project does not have a fints folder, right−click the root folder for your project, and add a folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
listFormElement.optionFontSize: Specifies the font size for the options list. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionFontStyle: Specifies whether the options list is italic. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionFontWeight: Specifies whether the options list is bold. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.optionLineHeight: HSpecifies the height of the option text in the dropdown list.
listFormElement.options: Specifies a comma−separated set of options for this list component.
listFormElement.optionTextDecoration: Specifies whether the options list is underlined. Not supported in all browsers.
listFormElement.showArrow: Determines whether an arrow graphic appears in the component, indicating a drop−down list.
listFormElement.textDecoration: Specifies whether the selected option is underlined.
listFormElement.value: Sets or returns the currently−selected list option.
listNode.actions: Returns a table of the actions that can be taken on this node, such as overriding it. Each row of this table contains a nested table that lists the parameters of that action. To view a nested table, drag a Table dataflow block into the dataflow window, and drag the cell containing the table onto it.
listNode.children: Returns a table that lists the children of the specified node.
listNode.metadata: Returns a table that lists metadata about the specified node.
listNode.mode:
Determines which children of this node are listed.
  • all: All children
  • points: Only nodes representing data points
  • actions: Only nodes representing actions
  • nodes: Only nodes that are not points or actions
listNode.name: name
Returns the name of the node.
listNode.path: Specifies the absolute location of the node to get metadata for. Drag the relevant node from the Data panel to this field.
listNode.profile: The DSA profile of the node: data type, optional URL for device description, and booleans indicating whether the node has a real-time value associated with it, whether it has historical data, and whether it supports stream subscription.
listNode.resolveActions: Enables creation of an output table describing available actions for this node's children. By default, this property is disabled.
liveUpdate:
Specifies when the user's changes to this component are committed. This property affects changes made in Preview Mode, the Viewer, and the deployed application. It does not affect changes that you make within the Property Inspector.

TRUE: Changes are committed constantly, as the user makes them.

FALSE: Changes are committed only when focus leaves the component.
loadHistories.autoRun:
Specifies whether the histories are loaded automatically.

TRUE
The histories are loaded every time any property is changed, including the first time that the path property is populated.

FALSE
The histories are loaded only when the invoke property is triggered, or at the specified interval.
loadHistories.dataInterval: Specifies the date or time interval between each consecutive pair of data points.
loadHistories.delta:
Specifies what is in each value column of the output table.
  • None — the value collected at the given time
  • With previous — the difference between the values in this row and the previous one
  • With next — the difference between the values in this row and the next one
loadHistories.enabled:
Specifies whether the history loader is enabled.

TRUE: The histories load as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE: The histories do not load.
loadHistories.header:
Specifies which string is used to name each value column in the output table.
  • Default — the default string "vn"
  • Name — the name of the data node for which this is a history
  • Parent — the name of the data node's parent
  • Parent_Name — the names of both this node and its parent
loadHistories.interval: Specifies how often the histories are loaded, in seconds. A value of 0 means that they are reloaded on autoLoad or invoke only.
loadHistories.invoke: Causes the histories to be loaded. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
loadHistories.loading: Returns whether the histories are currently loading.
loadHistories.missingValue:
Specifies what value to display if there is no data collected for a certain interval.
  • Null — a null value
  • Use previous — the value for the previous timestamp
  • Use next — the value for the next timestamp
  • Interpolate — the average between the previous and next timestamps
  • Zero — zero
loadHistories.output:
Returns a table of the given histories' values. Columns are:
  • timestamp — the time when the data was collected.
  • vn — the first data node's value, or its delta if specified.
  • status (if specified) — the status of the data node at the time of collection. Can sometimes be used to indicate the reliability of the data.
loadHistories.paths:
Specifies the histories that this block loads. To specify the histories:
  1. Click the Expand icon to open a loadHistories.paths panel.
  2. In the Data panel, click the relevant device or data source.
  3. In the Metrics panel, select a relevant device point, and drag its History icon to the loadHistories.paths panel.
  4. Press Alt + Enter to create a new line.
  5. Repeat steps 2—4 until all paths are entered.
loadHistories.rollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used. Options are:
  • Avg — the average of all number values for the interval
  • Min — the smallest number value for the interval
  • Max — the largest number value from the interval
  • Sum — the sum of all number values for the interval
  • First — the first value for the interval
  • Last — the last value for the interval
  • Count — the number of non−null values that exist for the interval
loadHistories.showStatus: Determines whether a status column is included for each history in the output table. Status values report the status of the node data at the time that data was collected, such as "down" or "overridden." This can indicate the reliability of the value.
loadHistories.timeout: Specifies how long the block attempts to load the histories before the request is canceled.
loadHistories.timeRange: Specifies the date and time range to return the histories for. You can click the button and use the date range picker to specify a range.
loadHistory.autoRun:
Specifies whether the history is loaded automatically.

TRUE
The history is loaded every time any property is changed. This includes the first time that the path property is populated.

FALSE
The history is loaded only when the invoke property is triggered, or at the specified interval.
loadHistory.dataInterval: Specifies the date or time interval between each consecutive pair of data points.
loadHistory.delta:
Specifies what is in the "value" column of the output table.
  • None — the value collected at the given time
  • With previous — the difference between the values in this row and the previous one
  • With next — the difference between the values in this row and the next one
loadHistory.enabled:
Specifies whether the history loader is enabled.

TRUE: The history loads as specified by invoke, autoRun, and interval.

FALSE: The history does not load.
loadHistory.header:
Specifies which string is used to name the "value" column in the output table.
  • Default — the default string "value"
  • Name — the name of the data node for which this is a history
  • Parent — the name of the data node's parent
  • Parent_Name — the names of both this node and its parent
loadHistory.interval: Specifies how often the history is loaded, in seconds. A value of 0 means that the history is reloaded on autoLoad or invoke only.
loadHistory.invoke: Causes the history to be loaded. Only works if enabled is set to TRUE.
loadHistory.loading: Returns whether the history is currently loading.
loadHistory.output:
Returns a table of the given history's values. Columns are:
  • timestamp — the time when the data was collected
  • value — the data node's value, or the delta if specified
  • status — the status of the data node at the time of collection. Can sometimes be used to indicate the reliability of the data.
loadHistory.path: Specifies the history for which to return information.
loadHistory.rollup:
Specifies the type of rollup used. Options are:
  • Avg — the average of all number values for the interval
  • Min — the smallest number value for the interval
  • Max — the largest number value from the interval
  • Sum — the sum of all number values for the interval
  • First — the first value for the interval
  • Last — the last value for the interval
  • Count — the number of non−null values that exist for the interval
loadHistory.timeout: Specifies how long the loader attempts to load the history before the request is canceled.
loadHistory.timeRange: Specifies the date and time range to return the history for. You can click the button and use the date range picker to specify a range.
loadValue.enabled: Specifies whether the Load Value block updates when the node's value changes.
loadValue.format: The format string to be applied to the value being loaded. The result is returned in the formatted property.
loadValue.formatted: Returns the formatted value. For example, for a numeric value, it returns a string that includes units. For an enum or boolean value, it returns the string associated with the value.
loadValue.lastUpdate: Returns a string indicating when the node was last updated.
loadValue.path: Specifies the node for which to return information.
loadValue.qos:
Specifies persistence as follows:
  • 0 — The real-time value is loaded and is replaced with new values in real time.
  • 1 — The real-time value is loaded, output in a table, and replaced with new values in real time. If more than one value is loaded in a request, multiple rows appear in the table. The output is intended to be used with a threaded dataflow repeater in stream mode.
  • 2 — Intended only for remote dataflow. The real-time value is loaded, is output in a table, and is replaced with new values in real time. Only one row appears in the table. If the connection is lost, values persist on the server, and the most recent value is sent to the client when the connection is restored.
  • 3 — Intended only for remote dataflow. The real-time value is loaded, is output in a table, and is replaced with new values in real time. If more than one value is loaded in a request, multiple rows appear in the table. If the connection is lost, values persist on the server, and all values stored on the server are sent to the client when the connection is restored. The output is intended to be used with a threaded dataflow repeater in stream mode.
For a qos of 1, 2, or 3, you can access table cells by binding the value property to a Table block.
loadValue.status: Returns the status of the node, if applicable, such as "down" or "overridden." It can indicate the reliability of the value.
loadValue.unit: Returns the units of the node.
loadValue.value: Returns the current value of the node, if enabled is TRUE. Returns the last collected value of the node, if enabled is FALSE.
localStorage.global:
Specifies whether this block sets and returns the global or non−global value for the key.

TRUE: This block sets and returns this user's global value for the key, which stays consistent over any project.

FALSE: This block sets and returns this user's non−global value for the key, which applies only to this project.
localStorage.key: Sets or returns the key for a key−value pair.
localStorage.value: Sets or returns the value for a key−value pair.
log.base: Specifies the base for the logarithm.
log.input: Specifies the number to get the logarithm for.
log.output: Returns the logarithm for the specified input and base.
longitude: Sets or returns the longitude at the center of the map component.
loop:
Determines whether the animation sequence is repeated.

TRUE: As soon as it is complete, the animation starts again.

FALSE: The animation happens once, and then the image defined by the URL property is displayed.
mainValueAxis: Specifies the axis (x or y) on which values are displayed. By default, values are displayed on the y axis (vertically).
makeObject.outputObj: Returns a JSON object that comprises the input key/value pairs.
map.filter: For MapGL layers, specifies the table column and value that determine what points to display, if you need a simple way to reduce the data displayed on the layer.
map.imageMaxZoom: Sets the maximum zoom level for the map when displaying image tile overlays.
map.imageTileSize: Specifies the size of map tiles.
map.latField: Specifies the column in your table that contains latitude data.
map.lngField: Specifies the column in your table that contains longitude data.
map.mapControls: Specifies whether to show map controls, allowing the user to manipulate the map. Map controls allow the user to zoom in or out and move left, right, down, or up.
map.mapStyle: For MapGL components, specifies the URL of the style sheet to be used to style the map.
map.mapType:
Specifies the type of Google Map to be displayed in the component.
  • Roadmap: The default road map view.
  • Satellite: Google Earth satellite images.
  • Hybrid: A mixture of road map and satellite images.
  • Terrain: A physical map based on terrain data.
map.maxZoom: Specifies the largest zoom level permitted for the map.
map.minZoom: Specifies the smallest zoom level permitted for the map.
map.trafficLayer: Specifies whether to show the Google Maps Traffic Layer on the map.
map.zoom: Sets or returns the zoom level for the map. Zero is the lowest zoom level, in which the entire world can be seen in one map. The maximum zoom level depends on available data and is typically between 18 and 21.
mapGeoJSON.circleColor: Specifies the color of the default marker.
mapGeoJSON.circleOpacity: Specifies the opacity of the default marker.
mapGeoJSON.circleRadius: Specifies the radius in pixels of the default marker.
mapGeoJSON.circleStrokeColor: Specifies the color of the outline around the default marker.
mapGeoJSON.circleStrokeOpacity: Specifies the opacity of the outline around the default marker.
mapGeoJSON.circleStrokeWidth: Specifies the weight of the outline around the default marker.
mapGeoJSON.dataKeyField: The name of the dataflow table column that contains the values corresponding to those in the geo Property field (for example, state names).
mapGeoJSON.dataValueField: The name of the dataflow table column that contains the value to be assigned to the style setting.
mapGeoJSON.geoProperty: The geoJSON field containing the values that will drive styling. For example, the 'NAME' field in the GeoJSON data might contain the name of the country described by the polygon.
mapGeoJSON.styleData: The table from which the GeoJSON layre reads style data.
mapGeoJSON.targetProperty: The map style property that you want to set, for example, fill-color.
mapGeoJSON.targetPropertyField: The table column from which the target property is read. The target property specifies the table property that you want to set.
mapGroup.symbol: Specifies the symbol to be used as a location marker in this map group. If the symbol is in this project, enter the name of the symbol. To use a symbol from another project in your library, enter the path to that symbol. A map group is useful when you want to have multiple repeaters, or other components, in your map, or when you want your markers to be placed at each set of coordinates without being centered on the location.
mapTileLayer.maxZoom: The maximum zoom layer permitted for the tile layer.
mapTileLayer.minZoom: The minimum zoom level permitted for the tile layer.
mapTileLayer.tileSize: Specifies tile size in pixels. For best results, specify multiples of 8. Smaller tiles provide better resolution at the expense of rendering speed. Maximum tile size is 512.
markerMap.circleColor: Specifies the color for standard markers.
markerMap.circleColorField: Specifies the table column containing the color to be displayed for the circle marker for the location described in the table row.
markerMap.circleOpacity: Specifies the opacity for standard markers.
markerMap.circleRadius: Specifies the radius for standard markers.
markerMap.circleRadiusField: Specifies the table column containing the radius for the circle marker to be displayed for the location described in the table row.
markerMap.cluster: Enable/disable marker clustering when zooming out.
markerMap.clusterIcon: Specifies icon to display for clustered markers.
markerMap.clusterLabelColor: Specifies color of label for clustered markers.
markerMap.clusterLabelOutlineColor: Specifies color of label outline for clustered markers.
markerMap.clusterLabelOutlineWidth: Specifies weidth of label outline for clustered markers.
markerMap.icon: Specifies the graphic to be displayed as a marker for the location described in the table row.
markerMap.iconField: Specifies the table column containing the complete path to the graphic to be displayed as a marker for the location described in the table row.
markerMap.offsetHorizontal: Specifies in pixels how much the marker is offset horizontally from the location on the map.
markerMap.offsetVertical: Specifies in pixels how much the marker is offset vertically from the location on the map.
markerStroke: Specifies the border stroke color for standard markers.
markerStrokeStyle: Specifies the border stroke style for standard markers.
markerStrokeWidth: Specifies the border stroke weight, in pixels, for standard markers.
markersType:
Specifies the type of markers used by this series. Markers are used to visually represent each data point in the series, in addition to the line or shape that represents the entire series.
  • None: No markers are used by this series.
  • Standard: This series uses a standard marker design, a circle with a customizable fill, stroke, and size.
  • Custom: This series uses the specified symbol as a marker.
mask: Specifies a CSS mask, which alters the visibility of a component by partially or fully hiding it.
maskContentUnits: For SVG components, specifies the >coordinate system for the contents of the mask.
maskUnits: defines the coordinate system for attributes x, y, width and height.
max: Specifies a maximum valid number for this input component. For range input components, the default maximum is 100.
max.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
max.output: Returns the greatest of the input values.
maxCharLength: Specifies the maximum number of characters allowed in this text component.
maxFontSize: Specifies the maximum font size for this text component. This property is only applicable when font size is set to Auto.
maxHeight: Maximum height of the component in pixels or as a percent of its container. The auto option means this property is not set.
maximum: Specifies the highest number on the scale.
maxWidth: Maximum width of the component in pixels or as a percent of its container. The auto option means this property is not set.
median.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
median.output: Returns the median of all input values.
min: Specifies a minimum valid number for this input component. For range input components, if the minimum is not set, the bottom of the range is zero.
min.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
min.output: Returns the smallest of the input values.
minFontSize: Specifies the minimum font size for this text component. This property is only applicable when font size is set to Auto.
minHeight: Minimum height of the component in pixels or as a percent of its container. The auto option means this property is not set.
minimum: Specifies the lowest number on the scale.
minorTickLength: Specifies the length of each minor tick.
minorTickPlacement: Specifies whether the minor ticks appear on the inside, outside, or center of the line that represents an axis.
minorTickStroke: Specifies the stroke color of the minor ticks.
minorTickStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight of each minor tick.
minWidth: Minimum width of the component in pixels or as a percent of its container. The auto option means this property is not set.
mode:
Determines the selection mode for the component.
  • Day: The user can select one day.
  • Week: The user can select one week. Selecting any date selects a week that includes that date. The week selected starts on a Sunday and ends on a Saturday, regardless of the currently selected First Day of Week.
  • Month: The user can select one month. Selecting any date selects its entire calendar month.
mode.0: Specifies one of the input values for the statistical function.
mode.output: Returns the mode of all input values.
modulo.quotient: Returns the integer result of input divided by modulo.
modulo.remainder: Returns the remainder. The remainder property always has the same sign as the input property.
monthNames: Specifies the month names that appear on the calendar, as a comma−separated list of 12 values. The first value is displayed for January, and the last is displayed for December. Must be 12 values in order for defined names to take effect.
mouseEnabled: Specifies whether this component responds to mouse events.
mouseEventData.active: Sets or returns whether this block is currently listening for the specified event.
mouseEventData.dragData:
Returns the binary data of the file that is dropped onto this component. To use this property, you must do the following:
  • Enable the droppable Advanced property for this component.
  • Set the dropGroup Advanced property for this component to file_png. You can also replace png with another file extension.
mouseEventData.dragSource:
Returns the ID of the component that is dropped onto this component. To use this property, you must do the following:
  • Enable the droppable Advanced property for this component.
  • Enable the draggable Advanced property for the component to be dragged.
  • Make sure that the dragGroup Advanced property is the same for both components.
  • Make sure that the dragGroup Advanced property is the same for both components.
mouseEventData.event: Returns the event type that this listener heard.
mouseEventData.fileName:
Returns the name of the file that is dropped onto this component. To use this property, you must do the following:
  • Enable the droppable Advanced property for this component.
  • Set the dropGroup Advanced property for this component to file_png. You can also replace png with another file extension.
mouseEventData.input:
Specifies the event that triggers this block. Make sure that you have selected the correct parent component for the event, and then find the event in the Advanced properties and bind it to this property. Examples include:
  • onClick — The user clicks the component.
  • onClickOff — The user clicks the component (paired with onClickOn).
  • onClickOn — The user clicks the component (paired with onClickOff).
  • onDoubleClick — The user double−clicks the component.
  • onMouseDown — The user presses the mouse button over the component.
  • onMouseEnter — The user moves the cursor onto the component.
  • onMouseLeave — The user moves the cursor off of the component.
  • onMouseMove — The user moves the cursor while it is over the component.
  • onMouseMoveGlobal — The user moves the cursor anywhere on the screen.
  • onMouseUp — The user releases the mouse button over the component.
  • onMouseUpGlobal — The user releases the mouse button anywhere on the screen.
  • onMouseWheel — The user rotates the mouse wheel either up or down.
  • onRightClick — The user right−clicks on the component.
mouseEventData.pageX: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the left page boundary to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are to the right of the left page boundary.
mouseEventData.pageY: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the top page boundary to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are below the top page boundary.
mouseEventData.x: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the left container boundary of the component to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are to the right of the boundary.
mouseEventData.y: Returns the distance, in pixels, from the top container boundary of the component to the cursor at the time of the mouse event. Positive values are below the top container boundary.
moveToTop: When set, visually moves the component to the top of its parent container. The order of components in the container and the outline is not affected.
multiply.0: Specifies one of the numbers to multiply.
multiply.output: Returns the result of multiplying all of the input values.
multiSelect: For container components, enables users to select multiple components in the container.
normalBackground: Specifies the fill for weekday cells.
normalBorder: Specifies the stroke color or border image for outlining each weekday cell.
normalCornerRadius: Specifies the corner radius for weekday cells, as arcs of circles or ellipses. The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the cell's width and height, respectively. A value of 0 means that corners are not rounded.
normalFontColor: Specifies the font color for numbers in weekday cells.
normalFontFamily: Specifies the font for numbers in weekday cells.
normalFontSize: Specifies the font size for numbers in weekday cells.
normalFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in weekday cells is italic.
normalFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in weekday cells is bold.
not.input: Specifies a value that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE. If input is a number, a value of 0 evaluates to FALSE and a value of 1 evaluates to TRUE.
not.output: Returns FALSE if the input is TRUE, or returns TRUE if the input is FALSE.
number.value: Sets and returns the value of this Number block or Constant block.
offset:
The Offset Operator is the operator that indicates how the source value and the Offset Value are used to create the target value. Possible values:
  • add — The source value and Offset Value are added together.
  • subtract — The Offset Value is subtracted from the source value.
  • multiply — The source value and Offset Value are multiplied together.
  • divide — The source value is divided by the Offset Value, and a decimal value is returned.
  • modulo — The source value is divided by the Offset Value, and the remainder is returned.
  • divide (int) — The source value is divided by the Offset Value, and the quotient is returned, rounded down to the nearest integer.
Examples

Source: 30
Offset: divide 8
Target: 3.75

...because 30 / 8 = 3.75.

Source: 30
Offset: divide 8
Target: 3

...because 30 / 8 = 3r6.

Source: 30
Offset: modulo 8
Target: 6

...because 30 / 8 = 3r6.
offsetLeft: Specifies the distance between the left side of a linear scale and the container bounds, in pixels. If a border stroke is defined, Specifies the distance between the scale and the border stroke. [More information]
offsetRight: Specifies the distance between the right side of a linear scale and the container bounds, in pixels. If a border stroke is defined, Specifies the distance between the scale and the border stroke. [More information]
offsetVal: The Offset Value is the number that is used together with the source value and Offset Operator to determine the target value.
onChange: Specifies the event fired when the user makes a change.
onEnter: Specifies the event fired when the user hits ENTER.
onLoseFocus: Specifies the event fired when the component loses focus.
onUpdateRepeater: Design time trigger to apply all changes to master series (recreate all generated series with changed parameters)
op: Specifies th eoperator to be used to evaluate.
opacity: Specifies the opacity of this component. If this component is a group or container, all components inside are affected.
openDashboard.dashboard: iSpecifies the name of the dashboard to open.
openDashboard.destination: Specifies where the dashboard is to be opened.
openDashboard.self: If the action page is inside a page include component, opens the dashboard in the page include component.
or.0: Specifies one of the input values. One or more of the input n values must evaluate to TRUE for the Or block to return the then value. For example, "input 0 OR input 1" is a comparison expression. If input 0 is TRUE and input 1 is FALSE, the expression evaluates to TRUE and the Or block outputs the then value. Otherwise, if both of the inputs are FALSE, the Or block outputs the else value. If input n is a number, a value of 0 evaluates to FALSE and a value of 1 evaluates to TRUE. To add more input n properties, click the plus sign.
or.else: Specifies the value to return if all of the input properties evaluate to FALSE.
or.op:
Specifies the comparison, arithmetic, or text operator to apply to the input values. The operator is used in conjunction with inputs to form an expression that can be evaluated to TRUE or FALSE.

By default, the op value of an Or block is "or". The block will not act as described if you change this property.
or.output: Returns either the then value or the else value. It returns the then value if all of the input n values evaluate to TRUE, and the else value otherwise.
or.then: Specifies the value to return if one or more of the input properties evaluate to TRUE.
orientation: Specifies the orientation of the output, portrait or landscape.
outOfMonthBackground: Specifies the fill for out−of−month cells.
outOfMonthBorder: Specifies the stroke color or border image for outlining out−of−month cells.
outOfMonthCornerRadius: Specifies the corner radius for out−of−month cells, as arcs of circles or ellipses. The circles or ellipses are defined using a pixel value or percentage. A pixel value is the radius of a circle. A percentage value Specifies an ellipse with horizontal and vertical radii that are that percentage of the cell's width and height, respectively. A value of 0 means that corners are not rounded.
outOfMonthFontColor: Specifies the font color for numbers in out−of−month cells. Selected cells style properties take precedence over out−of−month cell properties.
outOfMonthFontFamily:
Specifies the font for out−of−month cells. To add a font to your project and use it for this property:
  1. If your project does not have a fonts folder, right−click the root folder for your project and add a folder named fonts.
  2. Navigate to the font file on your computer and drag it to the fonts folder.
  3. Save your work and refresh the browser.
  4. Specify the font using the drop−down menu for this property.
outOfMonthFontSize: Specifies the font size for numbers in out−of−month cells.
outOfMonthFontStyle: Specifies whether the text in out−of−month cells is italic.
outOfMonthFontWeight: Specifies whether the text in out−of−month cells is bold.
outOfMonthStyle: For internal use, do not change.
output: Repeater output table: Contains one column for each rendered property and one row for each instance of the renderer, populated with current values of those properties per renderer.
paddingBottom: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the bottom container boundary and the bottommost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed. Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
paddingLeft: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the left container boundary and the leftmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed. Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
paddingRight: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the right container boundary and the rightmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed. Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
paddingTop: Specifies a number of pixels of space between the top container boundary and the topmost edge of the content. Negative numbers are not allowed.Padding is part of an object's width and height. [More information]
pageInclude.onContentLoaded: Event to fire when content has loaded.
pageInclude.onContentLoadFailed: Event to fire when content loading fails.
pageInclude.path: Specifies the relative or absolute URL of the .dg5 file to be used as a Page Include. This lets you use other .dg5 files as components within this file. To specify a file, either type a URL in the field, click the folder to specify a path, or drag a .dg5 file from the Project panel to the field.
pageInclude.reload: Refreshes the .dg5 file within this Page Include.
parseDateTime.day: Returns the day of the month as a number from 1 to 31.
parseDateTime.hour: Returns the hour of the day as a number from 0 to 23.
parseDateTime.input: Specifies the serial number or any supported date time string. [More information]. This can also be text from which a date can be parsed.
parseDateTime.millisecond: Returns the millisecond of the second as a number from 0 to 999.
parseDateTime.minute: Returns the minute of the hour as a number from 0 to 59.
parseDateTime.month: Returns the month of the year as a number from 1 to 12.
parseDateTime.second: Returns the second of the minute as a number from 0 to 59.
parseDateTime.weekday: Returns the day of the week as a number from 1 to 7. The number 1 represents Sunday, and the number 7 represents Saturday.
parseError: Indicates whether the block encountered an error. An error might be caused by improperly formatted input.
parseNumber.input: Specifies the string from which to extract a numeric value.
parseNumber.output: Returns the first numeric value parsed from the input string.
percentOriginX: X position for drawing center point.
percentOriginY: Y position for drawing center point.
percentRadius: Specifies the radius of the circle that Specifies the scale, as a percentage of either half the width or half the height of the container, whichever is larger.
perspective: For 3D−transformed components, specifies how many pixels the component is placed from the view. Note that the child components of the component get the perspective view, not the component itself.
perspectiveOriginX: Specifies where a 3D−transformed component is placed on the X axis.
perspectiveOriginY: Specifies where a 3D−transformed component is placed on the Y axis.
pieSeries.calloutGap: Specifies the amount of empty space, in pixels, that is added to the gap between the edge of the pie and the edge of the labels. Does not define the entire gap, but rather the amount that is added to the default gap. A negative value makes the gap smaller than the default.
pieSeries.calloutStroke: Specifies the stroke color for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.calloutStrokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.calloutStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for the wedge callout lines.
pieSeries.colorField:
Specifies the table column that contains data from which to determine wedge colors. The following formats are supported:

  • #EEE — any shortened, three−digit hexadecimal color string, including the # symbol.
  • #FF00FF — any hexadecimal color string, including the # symbol.
  • rgba(255, 0, 0, 0.5) — any RGBA color string, including "rgba" and the parentheses.
Alternatively, you can specify colors in the Property Inspector by expanding Wedge Fills.
pieSeries.dgFills: Specify colors for the pie wedges in this series. Click Add to add a color. To edit a color, click it. Colors are used in order, with the top color corresponding to the top row of table data. The Color Field property overrides this property.
pieSeries.dgWedgeLabel: Configures the text displayed in wedge labels for this series. Use the same tags you would use for a datatip.
pieSeries.explodeRadius: Specifies the distance that the series is exploded, as a percentage of the outer radius of the chart. Wedges move away from the center by this distance without changing their shape.
pieSeries.field: Specifies the table column that contains the pie chart series data that determines wedge size.
pieSeries.innerRadiusInPixels: Returns the inner radius of the pie chart in pixels.
pieSeries.labelPosition:
Specifies the position of the labels.
  • None: No labels.
  • Outside: Labels are positioned for each wedge, near the outer edge of the pie series. Labels might be inside or outside the wedges, depending on the outer radius of the series. < /li>
  • Callout: Labels are positioned outside of the chart, with callout lines. < /li>
  • Inside: Labels are positioned inside each pie wedge. < /li>
  • Inside with Callout: Labels are positioned inside each pie wedge when possible.If a label can 't be positioned inside, it is positioned outside of the chart, with a callout line.
pieSeries.outerRadiusInPixels: Returns the outer radius of the pie chart in pixels.
pieSeries.radialStroke: Specifies the stroke color for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.radialStrokeStyle: Specifies the stroke style for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.radialStrokeWidth: Specifies the stroke weight for the edges between wedges. To edit the inner and outer circles of the pie chart, use the Fill and Stroke properties for the series.
pieSeries.renderDirection: Specifies the order in which wedges are rendered.
placeholder: Specifies the placeholder text displayed in this input component when there is no input text.
power.input: Specifies the value to be raised to an exponent.
power.output: Returns the result of the calculation.
power.power: Specifies the exponent to be applied to the input value.
preserve3d: When enabled, specifies that child components will preserve their 3D position after the componet is transformed.
projectInfo.description: Returns your description of this project. Add a description by selecting Project > Project Properties.
projectInfo.isDesigner:
Returns whether the project is currently open in Edit mode.

TRUE: The project is open in Edit mode.

FALSE: The project is open in Preview mode or the Viewer.
projectInfo.projectId: Returns the automatically−generated unique ID of this project.
projectInfo.superUser: Returns whether the currently logged in user is a Super User.
projectInfo.user: Returns the currently logged in user for this session.
projectInfo.version: Returns the version number you have given to this project. Add a version number by selecting Project > Project Properties.
queryBinding.0: A data mapping compares a binding's source value to one or more Case values in order, until the statement it is evaluating is TRUE:. For numbers, a data mapping checks whether the source value is less than or equal to the Case value. For other data types, the data mapping checks whether the source value is equal to the Case value. When the first TRUE statement is encountered, that Mapping value is assigned to the binding's target. If none of the statements are TRUE, then the default value is assigned to the binding's target. More complex case mappings can be created in the dataflow using the Case block.
queryBinding.default: A value to assign to the target if none of the expressions are TRUE.
queryBinding.scaleInputMax: The upper bound of the original scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
queryBinding.scaleInputMin: The lower bound of the original scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
queryBinding.scaleOutputMax: The upper bound of the new scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
queryBinding.scaleOutputMin: The lower bound of the new scale. A scale binding takes the source value's relationship to an original scale and returns the corresponding value on a new scale.
radius: For standard markers, specifies the marker radius in pixels. For custom markers, specifies the largest radius of an inscribed ellipse, in pixels. This property is equal to half the symbol width or half the symbol height, whichever is larger.
rangeFormInput.ticks: Specifies values where ticks appear on the range selector, as a list of comma−separated values.
rawSvgRepeater.borderOffset: Specifies the distance into the dash pattern to start the dash.
rawSvgRepeater.borderPattern: Specifies the pattern of dashes and gaps used to be used, specified as a comma−separated list of lengths.
rawSvgRepeater.data: Specifies the table that controls the SVG repeater. The SVG component repeats once for each row in the table. Table columns can be used to represent attributes of the SVG component, such as style or coordinates.
rawSvgRepeater.dataTipSymbol: Specifies the symbol that appears as a datatip when mousing over an instance of the SVG in this repeater.
rawSvgRepeater.svgDefs:
Specifies the <defs> component for the repeated SVG component. The following example specifies a style for the repeated SVG rectangle. The style includes a green fill and a black border stroke.

Example: <style>rect{fill:green;stroke:black;}</style>
realtimeRecorder.0: Specifies a column name for the value n values in the output table.
realtimeRecorder.1: Specifies a value to monitor and output in the output table.
realtimeRecorder.bufferSize: Specifies the number of rows that the output table can hold. When the buffer is full, the oldest rows are deleted from memory.
realtimeRecorder.enabled: Determines whether the block is currently recording and creating a table.
realtimeRecorder.output: Returns a table of timestamps and values. The table contains a row for each monitored change.
relativize.output: An instance of the relativizing service. Click the button to interact with the service. For details, watch the video Introduction to Relativization.
